author: @usein_mata
text: it's just me returning to remind myself 😔 if we kenyans forget what this government did, we become accomplices to the blood that stains our soil. broken promises lie like shattered glass beneath the feet of grieving mothers, while the dreams of our youth are buried beneath the weight of bullets and betrayal. they asked for jobs—they got coffins. they demanded justice—they met silence. the government didn’t just fail us; it preyed on our future. if we forget, we abandon the memory of those whose only crime was to hope.

author: @PrincessAnneKageha
text: as a young person, watching the bbc documentary blood parliament from the day this was uploaded was both heartbreaking and empowering. it was painful to see how peaceful we were met with such brutal force, especially knowing they were just fighting for a better future. but at the same time, i felt proud of how boldly and creatively young people came together, using social media and their voices to demand justice. it reminded me that we have power, and that even in the face of violence, truth cannot be silenced. this is too painful though...💔💔💔

author: @BeHonorable244
text: i believe in order for change to occur, we also have to change. but we should also remember that change is a slow poisson. we elected ruto and these are the consequences of that election. we need not let our emotions dictate our vote in the coming election...we need to be strategic in choosing our next leader. do not forgive and do not forget...all should keep a meticulous account of all transgressions so that we can refer to them when the time comes. patience is key and emotional detachment is the whip...that is the end game. listen and listen well kenyans, i will say this only once...this world deals in emotional currency...they control you via your emotions. they want you to feel this type of way so that it becomes easier for them to control you. if we elect the new leader via our emotions, we will elect a new leader three times as worse as ruto ever was or could be, simply because we will all be blinded by hate, anger and pure rage. detach from your emotions and you will see the entire playing field...you will see the entire game and you will elect a leader who will merit the seat but also remember that there are those who control that seat. the power behind the power...ruto is but the puppet..there are the puppet masters...who operate in the shadows. so my question is, is ruto really the problem or just a symptom of a malignant tumour in the country we call kenya? who really makes these laws and pushes these agendas...these are the ones we need to root out...these are the source of our problems in this country.

author: @loughrey101
text: if the very purpose of the protests was to force their way into the parliament that how could that by any possible logic be defined as a peaceful protest? the protesters were effectively no different to the trump rioters who tried to force their way into the us congressional buildings in order to stop the certification of president biden as president, while in this case, their attempt was to stop the certification of the finance bill. they are both exactly the same situations and video footage shows that the protesters did indeed turn to violence towards the police. while it is a tragedy what happened, there is absolutely no possible way to define what the protesters were trying to do as anything close to peaceful. a peaceful protest is one that simply defined as a large group of people walking through the street and communicating their frustrations, but if the objective is to force your way into a parliament building then that by its very definition is a violent protest.

author: @Airlane1979
text: "the documentary fails to explicitly indict ruto and the government for the killings. kenya’s police have a long history of acting with impunity, repeatedly implicated in extrajudicial killings, torture, and disappearances, particularly against social opposition to austerity, corruption and soaring costs of living. the year before, anti-austerity protests led by the opposition were violently supressed, leaving at least 31 people dead and injured hundreds. no serious reckoning has ever taken place. it also pays no attention to the role of imperialist powers. behind closed doors, washington, london, and european capitals alongside the international monetary fund (imf) were working with ruto. their concern was not kenyan lives, but the risk that the protests could destabilise its key regional ally and capitalist regimes across the continent. they advised ruto to temporarily withdraw the finance bill and stagger the imposition of austerity measures to defuse public anger, while continuing to fund and train the military and police. that the bbc is the official voice of british imperialism, cloaked in a fiction of neutrality, is beyond dispute. but kiarie, and the rest of the kenyan political class, are stooges of imperialism. the politicians denouncing the bbc have signed defence cooperation agreements to maintain british military bases in kenya, while ruto himself paid tribute to queen elizabeth ii, the monarch who presided over the brutal suppression of the anti-colonial mau mau uprising that left hundreds of thousands dead. britain remains kenya’s largest european investor, a key donor of development aid, and a strategic partner in military and counterterrorism operations. the arrest of the filmmakers epitomizes the profound crisis of legitimacy facing the kenyan bourgeoisie, which is rapidly sliding back into the authoritarianism of the dictatorship of daniel arap moi under whom president william ruto was a loyal protégé. confronting this descent into barbarism demands the unified mobilisation of the working class on a socialist programme. armed with the lessons of history and guided by the principles of internationalism, workers and youth in kenya must join their struggles across borders in africa, in the united states, europe, and beyond." ('kenyan filmmakers arrested in crackdown over bbc exposé of gen-z massacre', world socialist web site, 4 may 2025)

author: @dra_allan
text: as a ugandan, watching the bravery of kenyan citizens standing up to their government gives me both hope and deep sadness. hope—because it shows that united voices can shake systems. sadness—because in uganda, our reality is even darker, and yet the world rarely pays attention. if the kind of investigative journalism being done on kenya’s parliament protests was also done in uganda, we would be extremely grateful. here, the situation is far worse. our police and army don’t use rubber bullets—they use live ammunition. people are abducted in broad daylight, tortured in unknown locations, and many are never seen again. even more shocking is that general muhoozi kainerugaba, the son of president museveni and the chief of defence forces, openly admitted on twitter that he's behind these abductions. yet nothing has been done to hold him accountable or protect the people of uganda. as we approach our general elections in 2026, the fear among ugandans is growing. we’re pleading with international governments, human rights organizations, and media houses like the bbc to turn their eyes to uganda. what’s happening here is not just politics—it’s life and death.

author: @TruthSetter
text: what the bbc is doing right now is not journalism. it is narrative control. they waited until the fire cooled, until it was safe, and now they return to stir emotions and reframe the story to suit a global agenda. this is not just about kenya. it is about using kenya as a case study for a wider ideological message. youth versus power. digital rebellion against outdated systems. chaos sold as justice. they highlight voices that fit neatly into their script. loud, dramatic, and always positioned as victims turned heroes. these figures speak the language of the modern left. activism, resistance, liberation. but behind the curtain, it is often calculated, political, and self-serving. yet the media avoids scrutiny. instead, they glorify and amplify. meanwhile, those with conservative, traditional, or religious values are cast as obstacles. there is no room in the story for structure, discipline, or national identity unless it is being attacked or redefined. right-wing perspectives are dismissed or villainized. if you speak up for order or values, you are instantly labeled regressive. this is the core of the modern left-wing system: • it promotes wealth redistribution, even when it weakens local economies • it centers identity politics over individual merit, pushing race, gender, or sexual orientation as primary identifiers • it resists tradition, often attacking religious and cultural roots in the name of progress • it calls for open borders and global governance, even if it erodes sovereignty • it dominates global media, education, and activism platforms, controlling language and silencing dissent • it uses emotional manipulation with terms like “hate speech,” “patriarchy,” or “oppression” not to inform but to dominate narratives now that the country is going through strain again, with economic pressure and rising youth frustration, the timing of their return is not innocent. it is precise. it is strategic. they are reigniting old fires not to help, but to reassert control over the story. to play moral referee in a game they only watch when it serves them. this is not journalism. it is exploitation dressed as empathy. it is ideological warfare, and people should not stay blind to it.

text: they sat on this one thinking that we had forgotten. alot happened that day not just in nairobi but in different parts of kenya. young people were murdered everywhere. we shall not forget. how politicians paid goons to intercept our protest. yes there was destruction of properties but most of the properties belonged to the politicians. it's our taxes they built their empire with. we will not forget how y'all bribed our parents with 2kgs of unga so that they could stop us. we will not forget the githurai youths. we will not forget the killings and abductions. we will not forget how y'all laughed at us while we were burying our brothers. we remember the statements and speech. we shall never forget., it's us against you. i'm sure given the chance no young person would be existing in this country. ......

author: @AbdullahiDeeer
text: it is deeply troubling to see major media outlets like the bbc remain largely silent on the ongoing genocide in gaza. every day, innocent civilians—many of them children—are being killed, yet this devastating reality receives little to no urgent coverage. meanwhile, the bbc continues to highlight events from several months ago, ignoring the immediate and unfolding humanitarian catastrophe. this selective focus reveals a disturbing double standard and reinforces the perception of western hypocrisy in how global suffering is reported. media organizations have a responsibility to cover all human tragedies with honesty, urgency, and fairness. turning a blind eye to gaza while amplifying less pressing stories only deepens mistrust and alienation.

text: i think it’s important to highlight that the demonstrations weren't against the raising of taxes. they were against the increased corruption and mismanagement of funds that made the effort of increasing taxes futile. it made us kenyans feel like we were suffering for nothing since all the increased revenue was going into corruption. what really broke the camel's back was the open display of corruption by politicians and government affiliated individuals after taxes had been raised, showing their expensive lifestyles at a time when there was less money accessible to the average citizen. thank you bbc for the documentary❤. a part 2 should be in order for the other murders and abductions that occured afterwards.

author: @AbdullahiSheikh-om3cf
text: watching the bbc genz documentary investigative work takes me to a dark corner. it’s incredibly painful and heartbreaking to witness the senseless and cruel killing of young kenyans. i deeply condemn the lack of empathy and insensitivity by mandera mp, major bashir. this killing of these innocent individuals evokes memories of the 1984 wagalla massacre committed by the kenyan army. in memory of wagalla massacre victims - youtube for years, the army and police have been responsible for the deaths of the people of northern kenya. the insensitivity and disregard for innocent lives displayed by the northeastern kenyan mps is deeply troubling and cruel especially when historically their people have suffered under the hands of the army... one innocent life taken is two much.

author: @marywanja-qw6mc
text: kenyans will only heal and make better decisions in future if both the government and gen z carefully analyse their actions and each take responsibility to accept what they both did wrong and what they both did right and as a nation repent and ask god for peace. what is entailed in a peaceful demonstrations? was it followed according to the law? does a peaceful demonstration included insults, destruction of people's businesses, stealing, going beyond the allowed route for demonstration? what is the allowed measure of force by police in a demonstration according to the law? does the law allow killing, wounding, bullets, blood shed in a demonstration? according to the law, did both parties observe the law? if both did not follow the law, then the solution is to take responsibility to accept what they both did wrong and let justice take its place. my prayer is that god will find a place in our hearts as kenyans to help us forgive each other, correct our mistakes and always do what is right in all situations. oh god of all creation, bless this our land and nation, justice be our shield and defender, may we dwell in unity, peace and liberty, plenty be found within our borders.

author: @adisabrenda6055
text: honestly i have no i dea what is wrong with some kenyan people and politician they only care about where their intrest lie kj kiarrie the politcal representative of dagoreti he maintains his stand that the videos and pictures have been doctored they are using images from else where ete! here is my take ! the people opposing this were in their mansions ,luxurius houses during this they have no i dea what happened , me i ilive in mombasa and i was there i was comming from work night shift i found the gen z gatthering as a millenial i wanted to understand their message so i joined them we crossed nyali bridge all the way to town on foot we met a second group coming from likoni they had a peaceful protest i left to freshen up by the time i got back all hell had broken loose it was like hell on eath , someone was shot bullets and teargass everywhere , the boy was rushed to a nearby hospital and he never made it he died do you know how i know that ? ironically my mother works for that hospital she is the one who received him i posted on social media because i took photos my mom was mad she saw the post she was like " leave that place right now ,i dont want to be the one receiving your body !" they have just brought me someone and he did not make it !" get out of there right now!, so the boy died , a family lost a member others suffered gunshot wounds. now im sill in the middle of town square hell allover i try to look for transport i couldnt get any police are stll throwing teagass and bullets everywhere, me along with the people i was with decide to go to the edge of the city we were the first to get there so we got transportation, our driver was sneezing so much the conductor too because of the teargass as we were leaving the city what i saw will forever stay in my mind i saw the bigest crowd crossing nyali bridge on foot (remember back in the day on the news when they would report about war in central african countries and you would see people carrying their belongins and walking on foot ?) thats how it looked .it felt like i was losing my country my point is i was there , iam greatful for bbc because they told our story us who were there.

text: 1. the problem with most african leaders is making decisions when its too late. 2. most african demonstrations end up with violence once the police show up. i can give clear examples starting from this one, at first the citizens just wanted to show how they were not okay with the parliamentarians decision. but once the police started the shooting and all that it's when the protesters also started the violences. 3. im most african countries the police is not owned by the public, rather by politicians, in the name of protecting positions. 4. in most african countries, when a case is involving the ruling part, remains uninvestigated until change of government. or unless private parties such as media intervene. sometimes blood is even spread during investigations. why mama africa 😢

author: @JustHim-r2j
text: the bbc’s blood parliament shed light on the shocking events around the 2024 finance bill protests, but many disturbing developments remain uninvestigated. a follow-up is urgently needed — especially in light of the incoming finance bill 2025, which risks repeating the same cycle of public exclusion, government overreach, and elite impunity. unanswered questions remain about what happened after the documentary ends: the june 25th internet shutdown, reported extrajudicial killings, secret cremations, and how some of those branded as traitors were later absorbed into government roles. there are also serious concerns about cabinet reshuffles that seem to prioritize political loyalty over competence, while ordinary citizens continue to suffer without meaningful reform. many who stood up for their rights in 2024 paid the ultimate price, yet those who capitalized on the chaos now thrive. a blood parliament: part two could help ensure that the full truth comes out — and that history isn’t quietly rewritten @bbcafrica

text: jan. 6 style . people were baited to storm parliament and peaceful protest was hijacked by political gangs. the police retreated and allowed crowd occupy parliament.however, killing and slow investigations and prosecutions of rogue officers is where the government & kenyan political class on both aisles has failed completely also very little changes made in government financial policies, corruption levels and hypocrisy.the government has been unable to pass budget , also have increased borrowing, debt levels and slow disbursement of money from the exchequer. if we see a repeat of such protests plus govt excesses/ impunity ,then economy will go bust and be more unstable.this documentary will help pressure the government to act and stop dragging its feet regarding bringing police respinsibility of killings to the courts for prosecution.

author: @Coachayanle
text: while bbc is a respected media institution, it is important to note that in kenya, we enjoy one of the best levels of freedom. however, that freedom must have its limits. during the recent events, there were clear signs of a hidden agenda behind the sponsored gen z protests. while raising concerns about tax issues was legitimate, attempting to occupy parliament and calling for the overthrow of an elected leader would have thrown the country into chaos. kenya could have descended into serious instability — but by god’s grace, that did not happen. many of those being interviewed now ;appeared to be opportunists and clout chasers seeking personal gain. amid genuine protests, there were individuals who burned parliament and looted businesses in central nairobi, causing massive destruction to private property. in such an environment, it is unrealistic to expect the police to maintain full control. what we witnessed was a deliberate attempt to create anarchy, and media coverage like bbc’s, at times, appeared symptomatic of overlooking these critical realities.

author: @thedve
text: echoes of emborogo in the shadowed streets of emborogo, where the sun dared not linger past dawn, aria walked with a rhythm of defiance, her thoughts a quiet storm beneath the veil. she knew the regime's iron rod— a leader's grip like rusted chains, clenching the throats of the hopeful, silencing dreams with the crack of boots. from her window, she'd watched the curfews fall, tanks rumbling like thunder over cracked earth, and in her mind, the stories etched: fathers dragged away for whispered words, mothers weeping in the marketplace void. aria's heart, a fragile bird, fluttered with the weight of what must come— a march for the stolen, the silenced ones. she alone felt the pull, the unyielding tide, her perspective narrowing to this single path. the air hung heavy, thick with the scent of fear, emborogo's capital a cage of concrete and wire. aria gripped the flag, its fabric worn and faded, a symbol of unity, not war— red and gold threads whispering of better days. in her other hand, a simple bottle of water, cool against her palm, a reminder of peace: no stones, no rage, just thirst quenched in the sun. she thought of her brother, lost to the regime's purge, his laughter echoing in her mind like a ghost. "why this?" she pondered, steps faltering briefly, as soldiers eyed the growing crowd from rooftops. to aria, the flag was no weapon, but a plea for the light to pierce the dark, the water, a gesture of shared humanity. her thoughts raced: "we are not the enemy; we carry no more than what sustains us." yet, in emborogo, even breath could be treason. the square swelled like a heartbeat, voices rising in a chorus aria felt in her bones. she marched at the front, flag held high, its colors catching the fleeting wind. around her, faces etched with quiet resolve— farmers, students, mothers like her own, all armed with nothing but conviction. aria's mind fixated on the simplicity: a bottle to drink, a flag to wave, no hatred in their eyes, only hope's faint glow. but the iron rod loomed, unseen yet palpable, helicopters circling like vultures overhead. she wondered, in that limited haze of fear, if the ruler saw them as threats or mere ants. "they're innocent," she thought, scanning the crowd, "just people, like me, seeking a voice." then, the crack of gunfire shattered the air, a storm unleashed from the shadows. aria froze, her thoughts fracturing— the flag slipping in her grasp, water spilling like tears. bodies crumpled around her, innocent forms collapsing in pools of red, their only sins a bottle of water and a flag. she saw a young man fall, his eyes wide with shock, clutching the same simple burdens as she. in her mind, a scream echoed: "why? we meant no harm!" bullets whispered through the chaos, and aria's world narrowed to pain— a fire in her side, the flag torn from her hand. she hit the ground, vision blurring, thoughts tumbling into darkness: "this was not a battle; it was a plea." in the aftermath, emborogo's silence reigned, the square emptied, save for the fallen. aria's perspective lingered, fading slowly, as medics arrived too late for most. she thought of the water, now wasted on the pavement, the flag trampled under boots of iron. her final breath carried a whisper: "they killed us for dreaming, for carrying hope." the world outside might forget, but in emborogo, the echoes remain— a testament to the innocent, their story etched in blood and memory. ~lameck eo

author: @vasianichallengesjamenya8724
text: jung's writings, while not explicitly focused on democracy, implicitly address the need for a society where individuals can exercise their freedom responsibly. he believed that for a society to thrive, individuals must strive for self-realization and take responsibility for their actions, even in the face of societal challenges.

author: @vasianichallengesjamenya8724
text: in essence, jung's ideas about freedom and democracy go beyond the political realm, emphasizing the individual's journey of self-discovery and the responsibility to shape both their own lives and the world around them. he suggests that true freedom is not just about the right to choose but also about the ability to act with awareness, integrity, and a sense of purpose.

author: @andeyo1
text: if the government of kenya will not investigate the killings, abductions, and injuries of innocent and peaceful demonstrators, then it should not be surprised when others do it for them. bbc africa eye's blood parliament is not a foreign plot—it is accountability. the evidence is overwhelming: young kenyans were gunned down, abducted, and brutalized—not because they were armed rebels, but because they dared to raise their voices. what’s even more disturbing is the complete absence of government-led investigations or prosecutions. instead of seeking justice, officials are blaming "outsiders" for destabilization. let me be clear: what destabilizes a country is not journalism—it is impunity, corruption, tribalism, opulence, nepotism, and the primitive accumulation of wealth. it is the silence in the face of bloodshed. it is the betrayal of public trust and the abandonment of the rule of law. if the government truly believes in sovereignty and stability, let it prove it not with denials and distractions, but with justice, truth, and accountability.

text: there is insufficient concrete evidence to conclusively prove, beyond reasonable doubt, that the police officers featured in the alleged exposé footage were the actual perpetrators involved in the shooting of protestors. at the same time, the absence of definitive proof does not automatically exonerate them. as it stands, this appears to be more of a media-driven narrative than a substantiated investigation.

text: this mutahi ngunyi is a morally bankrupt individual who clings to his title and privileges with unwavering loyalty, not to the truth or the people, but to the very government responsible for shedding innocent blood. he speaks not out of conviction, but out of greed and self-preservation, defending the indefensible with rehearsed statements and hollow justifications. as long as his salary is paid, his bribes continue flowing, and his position remains secure, he turns a blind eye to injustice, shielding those in power while the nation suffers. to him, loyalty is a commodity, and silence—or worse, lies—is the price he willingly pays to stay in favor.

author: @philbertalfred9391
text: bbc releases political documentaries like this freely in africa to appear as champions of truth, justice and accountability. meanwhile documentaries like science, innovation and global discovery are hidden under subscriptions and geo- restrictions. the clear message is africa should watch corruption, poverty and protest but not future technology, climate science, space, or genius-level innovations. this is a form of soft discrimination not always in words but what they choose to fund, feature, and freely share.

author: @nkathagichunge182
text: a touching moment to remind us to appreciate the role of our journalists. to the journalists behind blood parliament, thank you for your courage, integrity, and relentless pursuit of the truth. your work has shed light on injustice and given a voice to those who were silenced. in the face of pressure and risk, you stood firm—for that, you have our deepest respect and gratitude. i just want to say thank you—from the heart. watching your documentary was deeply moving, and i can only imagine the risks and dedication it took to bring that truth to light. you didn’t just tell a story—you honored lives, challenged power, and reminded us why journalism matters. please know that your work has impact. we see you, and we're grateful. keep speaking truth to power.

author: @kenthelegendadvisor
text: the events of june 25th, 2024, in kenya were deeply concerning. the loss of life and the reports of excessive force used against protesters exercising their constitutional rights to assembly and expression are very serious. from an objective standpoint, several key aspects warrant attention: * the right to protest: peaceful assembly is a fundamental right in any democratic society. citizens have the right to voice their grievances and concerns without fear of violence or retribution. * use of force: the role of law enforcement is to maintain order, but the use of force must always be proportionate and necessary. reports of live ammunition being used against protesters, as well as attacks on medical personnel, raise significant questions about adherence to these principles. * accountability: it is crucial that there is a thorough, independent, and transparent investigation into the deaths and injuries that occurred. those responsible for any unlawful use of force must be held accountable in accordance with the law. * underlying issues: the protests themselves highlight underlying issues of public dissatisfaction with economic policies and the rising cost of living. addressing these concerns through meaningful dialogue and policy adjustments is essential for long-term stability. * impact on democracy: such events can have a chilling effect on civic engagement and erode public trust in institutions. it's vital for democratic processes to be protected and for citizens to feel safe in expressing their opinions. while it's important to acknowledge the government's responsibility to maintain order and security, this must be balanced with the protection of fundamental rights. the events of that day underscore the need for restraint, accountability, and a commitment to upholding the rule of law in handling public protests.

author: @QUEPID_K
text: 00:06 - violent protests erupt in kenya over rising taxes and government inaction. 02:56 - bbc africa eye investigates unaccounted killings linked to kenya's political unrest. 05:42 - kenya's june 25 protest escalates as citizens occupy parliament. 08:12 - mass protests escalate as protesters confront police and push towards parliament. 11:23 - analysis of violent events during the parliament incursion reveals tragic consequences. 14:52 - david chege's tragic death amid police violence during protests. 18:21 - police brutality against peaceful protesters raises urgent accountability issues. 21:09 - protesters storm parliament fueled by anger and fear during a chaotic demonstration. 24:18 - violence erupts during a protest leading to casualties. 27:15 - the shooter targeted protesters, resulting in eric's death. 30:50 - evidence suggests a soldier unlawfully killed eric shieni during protests. 33:58 - citizen activism drives demand for justice and accountability in kenya.

author: @otienosteven9692
text: bbc news should also uncover who killed tens of odm, cord, nasa and azimio supporters in 2007, 2013,2017 when police would enter people's houses and shoot their children before their own eyes and clobber the mothers to a near death. we also want to know why prior to elections then, their embassy issued a security alert that kisumu was a hotbed. we would like to know who gave the order to the police to take body bags to kisumu where tens of youths and men were killed and placed inside those things and dumped into the lake. was it the president then or cs for interior or it was the ig. who ordered for youths to be killed and dumped in river yala? has the family of moraa nyarangi, baby pendo and kianjokama brothers gotten justice? why were they killed? in fact, because they've existed before everyone alive here, they should also tell us who killed over 332 women and children in 1969 in kisumu when kenyatta visited the region for the opening of joorth hospital. we also need to know who killed tens of luos in kwale in 1997 to reduce their influence in the coast and lastly, we need to know who killed people in molo then too. who ordered for the mass killings of youths during the sufuria movement demonstration in 2023? when we want to fight extrajudicial killings, we would be very foolish and naïve to start from the end before solving the beginning. killing innocent or supposed guilty people should be condemned by everyone at all times whether it is done by government or citizens. no death is special than another. awacho ayueyo!!!!!!!!!!!

author: @ianmuroki5924
text: i've picked a lot of things in this documentary but what stands out is the stance taken by the political class headed by ruto, destruction of property was of greater concern to them than loss of lives. i'd love a detailed exposee on their stand since because ruto also gave a false account on the number of deaths. he said only 6 people were killed during a presidential round table that sunday evening when he also retorted "that child, he's alive right?" when asked about the young boy who was shot 8 times. yes there was destruction of property but surely the law is clear during disasters, life over property. global law for that matter. regardless, thank you for doing what local media couldn't do and for exposing the rogue forces both in the military and notorious police forces. history will be kind to you. gratitude from the kenyan youth ❤🇰🇪

author: @buildandmakewithnila
text: the question is tax rate in kenya higher than that in the uk, us or france? have people in us, uk and france gone on streets gone on streets to strike? "kenyans didn't visualize that it's tax that would build their country, not aid and grants. " this is the real independence ruto wanted to establish in not just kenya but also be an example in africa. for how long shall we africans keep begging, and the aid we receive comes at a cost. so i believe, taxation will help us build our nation with our own sweat just like the countries we see and admire today did. america was built by americans, japan by japanese, china by chinese, france by the french.... no single aid from anywhere. yes corruption is there, but it's a responsibility of every single citizen to fight corruption. it's only referred to corruption when it's not in the favour of an individual,but once it's favouring that same individual, then it's looked at as a connection (not corruption). this is a similar situation just like in us, uk, france... where tax payers money goes in funding political unrests, terrorism and wars causing distablisation across since they benefit from them. for instance, you've had citizens in western countries condemn actions of war in palestine, ukraine... etc, but do their governments listen? so each countries have ways to deal with their issues, and blaming the governments and supporting opposition against policies that would actually help their countries build themselves and be independent, should actually have a limit. lastly, kenya must be built by kenyans ,uganda by ugandans, nigeria by nigerians and africa must be built by africans ,not aid and grants 💪

author: @lifeofsin__
text: summary: the video provides a detailed recount of the protests that erupted in kenya on june 25, 2024, triggered by a government proposal to raise taxes amid rising national debt. over 100,000 people gathered in nairobi demanding accountability from their leaders, but the peaceful demonstration escalated into violence as security forces clashed with protesters. the narrative reveals the tragic deaths of three young men, shedding light on the government's response and lack of accountability following the conflict, while highlighting the profound social and economic frustrations among the youth in kenya. highlights: 0:05 the opening scene sets a dramatic tone with sounds of shouting and sirens. 0:29 introduction to the backstory of kenya's parliament and the proposed finance bill. 1:12 a pivotal moment as protests begin with over 100,000 kenyans marching towards parliament. 2:10 reports of casualties as security forces respond violently to peaceful protests. 2:31 president ruto claims that protests were hijacked by “criminals” while expressing regret for the deaths. 3:02 bbc africa eye begins its investigation into the events of june 25. 4:28 insights into the ongoing dissatisfaction with government corruption and economic policies. 9:25 the finance bill passes, despite protester opposition, marking a significant moment in the protest's narrative. 11:12 protesters break through police lines and enter parliament, marking a climax to the demonstrations. 18:28 the investigator highlights the brutal actions of police against peaceful protesters, questioning their motives. never forgive never forget

author: @MMNI24
text: as a kenyan youth, first of all i'm almost in tears seeing this again. terrible terrible memories . but all i have to say is that we kenyans tend to forget things so easily. if this doesn't make you think twice about the kind of people we elect as leaders and not just the president but even the mps, governors etc, then i don't know what will open your eyes to see that we are governed by people who have no consideration for the common mwananchi at all!! come 2027 i'm begging all kenyans not to forget that when all kenyans finally stood up to fight impunity, we were met with brutality and death. let us put the tribal and emotional politics aside for once and reason together once again as one people. let us make the right choices come 2027 because power belongs to us!! always remember that there are only two tribes in kenya, the political class and the common mwananchi . fighting amongst ourselves will never change anything. we have to come together against the oppressive political class if we are to save ourselves. please kenyans come 2027, let us not forget! let us not forget! let us not forget! . god bless the beautiful hardworking people of the republic of kenya and may the fallen heroes continue resting in peace🇰🇪🫡.

author: @dennismmwangid.m716
text: a day is coming sits on a golden chair, deaf to the cries that crack the air. we scream for bread, for peace, for voice— but silence is his cruelest choice. does not see the mother's tears, the father's jail, the youth's lost years. around him circle wolves in suits, corrupt, incompetent, taking loot. the parliament—no spine, no soul, they clap as freedoms lose control. the cabinet—no heart, no shame, they sign off torture in our name. the press is chained, the truth is slain, the brave who speak are lost, or maimed. a whisper now can cost a life, the night brings death, the day more strife. our ancestors bled on fields once red, for liberty—now cold and dead. their ghosts rise up in angry flame, to see their dream defaced with shame. but still, beneath this choking sky, the youth hold hope, they will not die. they carry fire in their chest, to light the path, to lead the rest. no tyrant stands forever tall, no empire stands that dares to fall. a day is coming—very soon, with ballots cast beneath the moon. the tyrant’s time will pass away, like shadow fleeing break of day. and from the ashes, peace will rise— with clearer hearts and brighter skies

author: @zimento_
text: just also keep in mind - this bbc doc being released in this manner + implicating certain agencies is absolutely by design. it’s systematic dissemination of information. it does not mean the info is false… it just means someone somewhere wants it out right now.. this way. one thing you’re taught in social sciences is to question everything. why now? why them? why this way? by who? for what? this is a skill we need to cultivate more of in society as we consume information. position determines perspective. some people will read this and interpret it to mean that we should not believe what we see in the documentary. we absolutely should believe it. the information is very compelling. be angry. act. but the layer beneath that? it says ‘never stop questioning’ - ever

author: @At254KE
text: if you're still supporting this political party after everything you've seen in this video, the lack of human intelligence — and conscience — is staggering. this isn’t just about politics anymore; it’s about right and wrong, good versus evil. if you choose silence now, remember: the tables always turn. pick your side carefully, because the internet never forgets — and history will not be kind to those who stood by injustice. the ones who lost their lives were not criminals — they were saints, standing for justice, for their brothers and sisters, when others stayed silent. and don't forget: when you corner a cat, it fights back harder than you ever expected. this moment demands courage. it's time to stand up — because what’s happening is wrong, and deep down, you know it.

text: i cried watching this it's so so sad 😭😭 yet this only shows the deaths of 3 men and still many more died that day including someone i knew literally a kid in highschool a footballer very talented was shot at club timba xo eldoret during the demonstrations he was unarmed and sadly he passed away.🥺. i can only imagine if the deaths of the rest were documented too🥺my heart really sunk watching this. i pray for all the families that lost their loved ones may god fill that gap ,that emptyness inside them. my heart bleeds for familes that's lost loved ones who did nothing but just speak out against corruption and the finance bill which was going to affect common mwananchi especially our young generation the genz while our corrupt leaders get rich off our small hard gained money yet no jobs we just wanted our voices to be heard, instead of being listened to we were killed mercilessly 😭😭 this is so sad . sometimes i wonder,do these people who killed us have emotions? don't they have kids back home that are the same age as the ones they killed during demonstrations? how would they feel if they received news that their child has been killed by a police officer while peacefully demonstrating ??? this is so heartbreaking. only god can help this country. may he take us out of this and give us good leaders who care about protecting it's citizens and listening to them and not killing them for expressing themselves. god take us away from this misery heal our nation and restore it 🙏🏽

text: for those insensitive people in the comments, you have brothers, sisters, cousins that you love and care about. most people who died from the protest are young people, gen z. what if it was your brother or sister you know mnaongea tu ju you haven't walked in the shoes of those who lost their loved ones kwani wewe ni shetani kusema those who died were criminals, ati bla bla bla what if it was you. shame on you police officers in kenya honestly you(police) are useless in the country, cause justice can't honestly be served if you don't give bribes ama your poor. lets not pretend what happened in githurai didn't happen it did. all those bodies found in kware, ati serial killer we aint stupid and worse a local was tasked to do this job of removing the bodies from the swampy area, a crime site filled will people just taking pic of bodies and posting online, we have no proper investigating or crime team. ruto how to you sleep at night. i will never forget 2024 june i will never forget seeing someones child on the side of the road lying brainless(sorry to that family), l will never forget hearing the police say "wacha wakufe tu" what? really someone tasked to protect the citizens, l will never forget all those who died during the protest, l will never forget kennedy onyango just 12yrs taken during the protest. ruto the pain you cost the country, l wonder how you are able to eat your good food after evacuating people from their homes to build useless small apartment at insane prices. thanks bbc

author: @hard_news
text: blood parliament: this documentary exposes killer cops. it must have been a lot of work. what a massive piece of investigative journalism! this is truly a remarkable achievement. piecing together facts and proving the injustice is not easy. this is why it is important to keep recording during demonstrations. a single angle, no matter how little of the suspected lawbreaker is viewed, may not show the whole picture but it matters in the built up to identifying suspects. another angle may unveil the truth from another demonstrator's perspective. the video is less than 24 hours and it has already hit 1.5 million views on youtube. the kenyan government is already requesting the national television not to air this investigative documentary report by the bbc and politicians are already blaming bbc for producing such a documentary that exposed the injustice.

author: @ChinaDailyWithWendy
text: i don't care what anyone says but the way police officers behave in kenya would have you questioning their qualifications. police officers should not be selected from academically deficient recruits. considering the immense responsibility they bear, including handling firearms and protecting citizens. it is crucial that individuals chosen for such roles demonstrate strong academic abilities and sound reasoning skills. lower academic thresholds risk compromising the quality of decision-making and public safety. how did they come up with a d+ which is equivalent to a gpa of 1.2 as a rightful qualification for becoming a police officer who handles firearms??? why did he just decide to be god and aim at an armed civilian with only a phone in his hand? how does he sleep at night knowing he did that to someone's son, brother, probably a father? may the soul of the departed patriots rest in peace.

author: @mayakalewis1291
text: thank you bbc for airing blood parliament, a powerful and timely documentary. it captures the horror of june 25th, when peaceful gen z protesters were brutally attacked a moment that forever changed kenya. as we face the 2025 finance bill and look toward the 2027 election, this documentary reminds us why we must stay vigilant. the anger against president ruto is real. he betrayed the people, crushed dreams with taxes and violence, and turned hope into bloodshed. kenyans have spoken: ruto must go. thank you, bbc, for giving voice to the truth!

author: @nicholasndungu1140
text: that's the day kenya felt the democracy and the freedom of expression like never before. united to the core with one voice and one agenda. provoked by the never ending promises and lies , with the most useless government in kenyan history which was shaken by the gen - z and it's remedy was to shed blood over and over just to remain in power. now to the reality is until i.e.b.c is able to contact election tomorrow if need be am afraid we won't have it on 2027. the dictator will play around as it has been going on since january 2023. am a father of four and two gen zs. so option of more blood isn't even on the table for at the end this is what holds the government. god is in control for in the midst of everything his throne is constant. let's pray and be still and watch god fighting for us. the damage done is beyond our understanding for can't count the real number of people died that night, thereafter and how many are quietly dying due to sha, shif, hunger and the list goes on....... only god is recording and knows all our burdens. let's turn to him sooner then it won't matter anything for the blood of jesus was enough to pay all our debts. meaning blood sacrifice no longer is allowed and god takes it upon his hand to whom is found with. am sure kenya will overcome and grow stronger but we need to pass this test together. shalom.

author: @eugenemurimi7181
text: their voices, once vibrant with the yearning for change, now echo only in the silence left by injustice. they took to the streets, their hearts ablaze with the hope of a fairer world, their courage a testament to the human spirit's refusal to yield to oppression. but their brave stand was met not with understanding or redress, but with a final, brutal silencing. each life extinguished in the pursuit of justice is a profound wound, a stark reminder of the cost of dissent and the urgent need for accountability. their blood cries out from the very ground they sought to reclaim, a testament to the ultimate betrayal when the right to protest becomes a death sentence. let us never forget their sacrifice, their unwavering commitment to a cause greater than themselves. may their memory fuel our resolve to dismantle the systems that steal lives and silence voices, ensuring that their fight was not in vain, and that true justice, the very ideal they perished for, will one day prevail." justice should be served 💯✅️

author: @mwendwajeff2417
text: i couldn't hold back my tears. the sequence of events during that day knowing that another death is coming is just tragic to watch. what makes it more worse is that the same people that were in power at that time when the country was almost falling apart are still in power today. and the same people that the gen zs were up against for failing to listen to the voices of the people today have regained their voices to speak back to kenyans. mps like oscar sudi who are close to president ruto still lecture us on what is right or wrong. kipchumba murkomen who was at that time constantly called out for a lavish lifestyle at the expense of taxpayers money is cs interior today. aden duale who was the cs defence then is today under the health docket as the man who has been entrusted to ensure the new healthcare works. the cs interior then who was supposed to be accountable for the blatant disregard if humanity and the constitution is today our deputy president. and yet we claim we have a country. we wake up everyday and go to work like june 25th never happened. we have let back these politicians back to our churches. some social media influncers are still willing to take up money to advance the agendas of some politicians. kenya deserves renaissance. after the june 25th protests i belive that something changed in kenya forever and soon maybe a little bit too soon everything will fall apart. i weep for my country. i take longer showers some days thinking about president ruto. i fail to understand how a man can hold that firm after such atrocities. it pains me that when african leaders hold ground when there is trouble it is treated as heroism. in the words of former us president barack obama," empathy is a quality of character that can change the world." president ruto failed to show empathy on the night of june 25th. up to date he still hasn't. and that is why kenya remains the same. i weep for my country.

author: @Allan_O._Muthiga
text: on the bbc documentary, rage manufacturers can't be objective. to them, this was the first time state violence was unleashed on protestors. is it rather so annoying when people forget the 80 people killed in 2023 as others cheered? at the time, wamunyoro boasted so much as he took operational command of the police to direct violence against supporters of odm. no comments from these hypocrites. the documentary followed the murder of three adult males aged between 27 to 39, actively participating in a protest that had turned so violent . imagine what would rage manufacturers say when there's a documentary about 6-month- old baby pendo, 7-year-old mutinda and 9-year-old moraa? those were young lives taken by the police - kids killed in their homes, with impunity, under their matiangi messiah. not in the streets or after storming parliament. and the discussion is not even about proposing a solution - such as a judicial inquisition with prosecutorial powers to investigate government excesses in the post - cok era. and neither can they discuss the decentralization of the npsc, including the re-structuring of the government to enable the effective devolution of certain police powers to prevent a recurrence. i am talking about 9 provincial governments with certain law enforcement powers devolved. how useful is the anger if it can't be channelled to productive use? this is precisely the reason i remain intolerant to the suggestions by the over excited and tactless morons who want odm back to the streets, with their 'we are back to the nyayo era' stories. because luos have borne the brunt of this violence, year in, year out as others comfortably warmed their seats and gave us lectures about the destruction of their businesses by 'people who have no stake in the economy'. let those whose lives matter more than ours take to the streets, at least their plight can be publicized. sisi huwa tunauliwa kama umbwa and nobody cares. we saw a government agency procuring body bags to kisumu ahead of the 2017 elections, and several bodies found floating on the lake days after the election. nobody cared.

author: @lekyphilip82
text: watching 'blood parliament' left everyone shaken to the core. it is heartbreaking to see young, unarmed citizens — full of hope for a better kenya — cut down with such brutality in a place that should symbolize democracy and protection. this documentary bears witness to their courage, their cries for justice, and the devastating cost of standing up against oppression. no people should ever have to pay for their dreams with their lives. the images, the sounds, the grief etched into every face — they will stay in our hearts forever. kenya deserves leaders who cherish life, not silence it. may the fallen never be forgotten, and may their sacrifice awaken a new spirit of accountability, dignity, and hope.kenya is bleeding, not just from bullets, but from betrayal. may history never erase their names."thank you, bbc, for your fearless journalism. 'blood parliament' gave a voice to the silenced and truth to the world. you honored the fallen with dignity and courage."

author: @antoniomaina
text: it is heartbreaking that we lost so many kenyans during the protests, at the hands of the very government meant to protect them. these were ordinary citizens — fathers, mothers, brothers, sisters, and youth — who bravely stood up to demand a better future. their only 'crime' was exercising their constitutional right to speak out against injustice. it is a tragedy that voices calling for change were met with violence instead of dialogue. we must honor their sacrifice by continuing to ask for a kenya where every citizen’s life is valued, where leaders listen to the people, and where justice and human rights are truly upheld. their memories must never be forgotten, and their dreams for a better nation must inspire us to push for meaningful change. my pride as a kenyan lies in the kenyan people themselves — in their outstanding bravery, resilience, and unwavering commitment to building a better nation. it is inspiring to see ordinary citizens boldly holding leaders accountable, demanding transparency, justice, and good governance. despite the many challenges we face, kenyans continue to rise, to speak up, and to push for positive change. their spirit of unity and determination reflects the true strength of our country. it is this courage and hope for a better tomorrow that makes me proud to call myself kenyan.

text: kenyans youth/ gen z have walked such a tightrope in our efforts to reclaim our rights which have been raped by this insensitive regime. the indiscriminate undescribable shooting of hundreds of unharmed youth whose only crime was because of asking that the government reconsider the punitive taxes clearly shows there is no commitment on the part of ruto's government to look into our plights. there are no job opportunities for us and when we decide to go for self employment the government targets our enterprises for taxes. i am told all the grievances that took us to the streets on 25th june 2024 have been reintroduced in the 2025 financial bill. we will continue suffering

author: @Argentbod
text: as a kenyan, watching blood parliament was both eye-opening and deeply troubling. the documentary shed light on the dark side of political power and corruption that has, unfortunately, become a norm in our systems. it's hard not to draw parallels with our own experiences, where power often overshadows justice, and people's lives are the cost of greed and manipulation. this is a call for all of us to hold our leaders accountable and demand transparency, as we’ve seen the dangerous effects of unchecked political power. powerful, yet painful to watch. we must continue to challenge these systems for a brighter future.

author: @paulmkavuwa
text: my dear brothers and sisters, i reach out to you with a heavy heart, humbled by the painful truths laid bare by this documentary. to every victim, every family that has suffered silently, and every kenyan whose hopes have been wounded , take strength and caurage in the lord. your pain is real. your voices deserve to be heard. and your dignity must never be forgotten. it is hard to find words that can ease the weight of betrayal and injustice. but i write to you with a message of hope: even in the darkest valleys, the spirit of kenya shines strong. we are a people born from struggle, faith, and unbreakable unity. what we face now demands more than sorrow , it calls for courage, for action, for a rebirth of the kenya we dream of. to the victims ,you are not alone. your stories matter. your courage in speaking out lights the path for a better tomorrow. to all kenyans , let us not lose hope. let us stand together, louder, stronger, and more united than ever before. let us demand a nation where justice is not a privilege but a right, where leadership is not stained by blood but built on truth and service. this is not the end of our story. it is a painful chapter , yes .but together, we can write a future filled with healing, dignity, and true freedom. let us find in each other the strength to rise. may god heal our nation and bless kenya always.

author: @djriggs8725
text: bbc needs to expand their research. the truth needs to be told in complete sentences, and you are missing a huge chunk of the story. basic commodities were taxed in 2022 by the previous administration. the previous administration organized the gen-z protests in a meeting called limuru three. get a translator and watch it. we had protesters who nobody had issue with (the ones talking here). nobody had issue withthem. but later on we had coup-plotters from that limuru meeting who were even robbing those same protesters you are talking to. those infiltrated the protests. everyone was afraid of them. ask any neutral party in the street (not these brokers you were inteviewing). that other group is what police was hunting for, they were extremely violent and they torched several buildings and even planned to invade secure zones like parliament, the airport and even staehouse itself. those were not protesters, they were anarchists. their aim was to topple the govt coz they had no assurances they would get political protection for the looting they had done to the point of crippling the country. that regime had robbed and killed people and they were looking for protection. ignore boniface mwangi, he is just a clout-chaser. you need to get the story from non-commercial actors.

author: @ONealCollins
text: the right to peaceful assembly is enshrined in both national and international law. the loss of life during protests is tragic and must be condemned in the strongest terms. the use of lethal force against individuals exercising their fundamental rights is unjustifiable. we call for immediate, transparent investigations into these incidents, ensuring accountability for all involved, and we urge the government to adopt nonviolent approaches to managing dissent. upholding human rights and the right to protest should always take precedence over the use of force."

text: extremely very sad. but meanwhile - we as kenyans must address our problems differently. our problem is that we have rogue & selfish politicians, and we also have the soros brigade - activists who create violent political riots for foreign funding and fodder for international media. both extremes are our enemies. solution - embrace the culture of political institutionalism. we need to emulate malema's eff. we need to do political lobbying using grassroots political organizations. we shouldn't follow the soros' brigade blindly. this documentary is actually theirs, not ours.

text: i have been spending most of the last 3 years in nairobi, and i was actually there during the unrest. i lived in imara daima, and i saw police and military fire rubber bullets and tear gas containers into peaceful protesters. here is the focal point and main reason for the unrest: in 2024, most young people, regardless of their education, would be happy to have a job paying 30,000 kenyan shilling. in 2024, if anyone had a job paying 70,000 kenyan shilling, they would already be considered as well-off (remark: that's around €530 per month): now let's look at what a member of parliament is making per month (and this is not taking into account that it is safe to assume that every one of them can easily double his income from bribes!): 750,000 mp base salary 150,000 housing allowance (plus a zero-interest, up to 35 millio loan to build a house 150,000 "adjustment" pay 350,000 allowance for car maintenance (plus a payment of 7,500,000 to buy a car, per parliamentary term, plus a mileage claim of up to 450,000) 120,000 maximum for attending the sittings of parliament total is then more than 1,5 million ksh per month, plus a superb free healthcare plan. that is 500 times the 30,000 kenyan shilling per month that most kenyans would be happy to have. and then the ruling party goes ahead and decides to put 16% vat on the most basic products such as rice beans, milk etc. but the people taking to the streets are the "organized criminals" lmfao

text: 20:03, grey shirt with dreadlocks is me. i recall ademba let out this wild scream when chege and mutisya fell, then pushed forward towards they bodies and we followed. i went home with a bloody shirt that day, for more than a week all i could smell was dry blood, even now typing this, it's deja vu. that smell never leaves your mind. my mum broke down when she saw me the following, she'd called my phone more than 50 times, had a total of over 100 missed calls from mum and 2 sisters. alafu ademba ni mzing 💪, if hadn't stepped forward that cop would've probably continued shooting and i wouldn't be here.

author: @s.kmacharia
text: after watching this bbc documentary, i now fully agree that kenya is not heading in the right direction. we are in a new era, and we cannot go back to the days of moi. i feel deeply for my brother, who died fighting for our rights. we will not tolerate this anymore. they only have two years left in power. young people, please, let us come out and vote this time. enough is enough. let’s unite and remove these people from power so we can finally deal with them properly. let’s stand together — this is a wake-up call for young people and everyone else. thank you to bbc news for shedding light on this. i was at the protests, and i can testify: it was bad.

author: @faridgetitusmgaya9556
text: as a tanzanian, i find myself overwhelmed with emotion—watching the strength, the unity, and the unshaken spirit of the kenyan people brings me to tears. it is not just a protest, not just a documentary, not just another headline—it is the heartbeat of a people crying out for justice, for dignity, for a better tomorrow. the courage i see in kenya is not ordinary. it is sacred. it is born from pain, from history, from a place deep within that refuses to stay silent in the face of oppression. watching those young men and women stand side by side, unarmed but powerful in their conviction, breaks something in me—and builds something too. i cannot help but wonder: what kind of heart does it take to fire live bullets at your own brother, your own sister, your own neighbor? they speak the same language. they share the same streets. perhaps they grew up playing under the same sun. and yet, in that moment of madness, the shooters forgot their humanity. but the people did not. the people remembered. the people held on to each other. and that is what africa needs. that spirit. that unity. that fearless defiance of injustice, even when the cost is high. we need to cry together. rise together. fight not with weapons, but with voices too loud to ignore. i came across a comment on tiktok that struck me deeply. someone asked, “why is kenya so silent?” and someone replied, “because of the documentary.” i paused, searched, watched, and wept. that silence is not surrender. it is mourning. it is respect. it is the echo of heartbreak across a land that has given too much blood to the soil. and yet, within that silence, there is thunder, a storm of hope and resilience, of people who refuse to let fear have the final word. to the heroes whose names we may never know, africa sees you. tanzania sees you. i see you. and i honour you.

author: @dukewabusia2186
text: good work bbc. allow me to engage you on as to why and how you chose people with questionable characters to feature except for the brave photojournalist ademba. your findings are that two of the victims are university students and then you leave it at that? connecting protests to university students and its organizers is very very easy especially if you have an mp who is also a product of the same rot. how i wish you had given us another angle of the calculated mayhem and destruction that was taking place under the guard of selected unifomed police officers particularly from h selassie avenue right down to ronald ngala street. why would protestors spend an entire day trying to get to parliament and once in they leave within five minutes yet the clarion call was occupy parliament, something spooked them while they were within parliament precincts. my eyes run with tears when i see how our brave young men were shot haphazardly by a contingent of uniformed offficers who were acting under instructions from unknown quaters. why didn't you investigate that. i mean even the officers were in on this one. it is evident. how do we have kdf infiltrating the kenya police without parliaments approval. brave young kenyans its high time we know who funded who and why. this documentary comes just a few days after our president went to the east and in a few weeks to come the budget will be read again, why are we being gaslighted yet already we have a budget proposal and everyone is quiet. go back to the national anthem and pray

text: i remember walking back home from town that day because there was no public transport by the time i was coming from cbd,i was so angry that vijana wetu wameuliwa.i over heard some guys who were just walking infront of us saying how if they had guns at this moment they would go back to parliament and go with atleast few of the mps and police guys who shot our boys.the anger we had as kenyans that day would have melted a rock.i saw men from maandamano crying because of losing brothers they are not related to.this documentary has unstitched a wound which i tried to cover up since that day.we will move forward,but we will carry the pain with us.

text: "institutions, not individuals, are the true foundation of government, africa and our country heavily lack this, that's why unlike the advanced democracies with powerful judicial/justice systems and institutions like the us, where every public official regardless of their rank in government can be held accountable, in kenya we lack such systems an institutions, we associate good governance with "good" leaders, while the advanced nations, have good institutions and systems to uphold the constitution with elected leaders being complementary and not supplementary", only when we have such systems, it won't matter who's president, because the institutions and systems in government will heavily correct and bring justice.

author: @susanngigi1164
text: 25th june 2024 😭😭😭. i was still at work in wilson airport quite oblivious of the extent of the damage in the city centre. the full impact of the day's events hit me when i made my way home in the evening. i was nursing a terrible seasonal flu and it got worse after coming into contact with the sharp sting of teargas remnants in the air of several residential estates that i passed through. people were being attacked here too.

author: @Charger_tales
text: i bleed for my country, kenya. every day, i watch the dreams of our people crushed under the weight of greed, betrayal, and broken promises. we were born free, yet we live like captives in our own land — captives to bad governance, selfish leadership, and the silence of those who should speak. corruption is a cancer eating our future, inequality a noose around the necks of the poor, and injustice a fire that burns our hopes. our leaders have forgotten that power belongs to the people. i will not stay silent while my beloved country is brought to her knees. i will speak, i will stand, and i will hope — for the kenya we deserve, not the kenya we are being forced to endure. we are not children of tyranny. we are the sons and daughters of freedom. and one day, kenya shall rise 🇰🇪 ✊🏽

author: @Zackie_Messenjah
text: thank you bbc for exposing what kenyan media is too lazy or too compromised to show. kenya’s image internationally is ruined and stained with blood. any investor or tourist who had intentions of coming to kenya must be having serious second thoughts. are we still africa’s most preferred destination? mr. ruto has lost legitimacy as a symbol of national unity and an ambassador of kenya's untapped potential to the world. he cannot be trusted with the sacred responsibility of leading this country anymore. ruto has lost people’s mandate. his hands are soaked with the blood of innocent kenyans. his regime thrives by suffocating voices of dissent and raiding the very souls of the people. this regime must be held accountable for violating the constitution and the basic principles of humanity. this is not democracy, this is dictatorship dressed in lies.

author: @godfrey1336
text: my greatest concern is how such images and documentaries depict kenya on the global stage. they perpetuate a narrative of conflict and chaos, overshadowing the broader reality of our nation as a stable, vibrant, and welcoming country, with democratic values and freedom of expression (which largely led to the chaos in the first place). this skewed portrayal severely damages our international reputation, deterring potential investors (hurting the nation even further and fomenting the same circumstances that led to the same chaos in the first place). bbc sees only instability and insecurity, but is that all there is to kenya? such sensationalist reporting unjustly equates us with places of perpetual turmoil, akin to regions like gaza. it is deeply disappointing that the bbc, in pursuit of ratings and sensational headlines, overlooks the implications their coverage has on an entire country striving for growth, prosperity, and a positive international image. we deserve balanced reporting that highlights not only our challenges but also our progress, the efforts of millions who wake up each morning to put food on the table and to develop our country, our record shattering athletes who continue to dominate the races, and the many positive stories kenya has to share with the world.

text: ive never felt so patriotic in my life like on this day. i saw people who are just as tired as i am of bad and corrupt leadership. if we don’t take ruto home, we shall be setting up our future african generations to repeats of this. we have to liberate ourselves. ruto has to go. corrupt leaders have to go. democracy has to take root in our lives. we are no longer stupid. yes, i’d do it again in a heartbeat. may these heroes rest in peace. history won’t forget you. and your families will find comfort in your courage.

author: @Mikejohn-bv9lu
text: the arrogance of the kenyan government is glaring in its refusal to cooperate with the bbc's evidence-based investigation. by withholding support rather than facilitating a search for truth, the government reveals a disturbing indifference to accountability. in a democracy, transparency should be a duty, not a favor — yet the leadership chose self-preservation over justice. such obstinacy not only damages public trust but also signals a leadership more concerned with its image than with the real issues facing its people.

author: @Bunyipp96
text: seeing this documentary evoked some emotions i thought i had processed and renewed my hatred for ruto. the fact that the bbc documentary humanised the victims is powerful and necessary. it gives dignity back to people who were stripped of it by both the rogue government narrative and biased coverage like sam gituku’s documentary, that tried to spin mps as the real victims. i am wondering why they had to deploy the kdf on civilians but then again, there's a deeper culture of impunity, where the leadership feels they can act violently and get away with it. we need to bring that one term president and his ghoulish mps to book. they should never, ever be allowed to get away with this.

author: @AYIMBARACHAEL
text: my heart bleeds. my eyes burn with rage. my spirit refuses to be broken. my ambition sharpens with every life unjustly taken. those killed are warriors, not victims — heroes whose courage will outlive those who tried to silence them. this is a journey to dismantle oppression, to reclaim the soul of kenya, and to prove that the spirit of a free people cannot be crushed by bullets or fear. it must be better. we must be better.

author: @djpraise9007
text: it is important to uphold human rights and ensure that all parties involved in any situation act within the boundaries of the law. accountability is crucial for maintaining justice and trust within a society. peaceful demonstrators have the right to express their views, and any use of excessive force should be investigated thoroughly. absolutely, ensuring transparency and enforcing consequences for human rights violations are critical measures. transparency helps build trust and accountability by making actions visible and understandable to the public. it empowers communities and individuals to demand justice and improved practices. enforcing consequences acts as a deterrent to potential violators and reinforces the seriousness of upholding human rights standards. together, these steps can foster a culture of respect and protection for human rights, preventing future violations.

text: i had not managed to go to the previous protest but the urge was growing.i was living with my younger sister and i took her with me.we were to meet up with my friend.whrn i got to cbd my mum called me....only to find out we are in the protest...my mum panicked.....later i find out my brother is in the protest too......we were around koja and the national archives... around 3-4 pm there was a sudden wave of sadness......and there was a signal to leave the cbd......i made sure i left with my sister and my friend and called my brother to tell him to leave.....i never witnessed this side of the story.after watching this.....i'm saddened......i hope we heal from all this ❤

author: @disturbed54times
text: it is a bittersweet video for me, more bitter than sweet. bitter at how the plights of our people were ignored in the days leading to the occupy parliament protests, then the demonstrations got intense, and they (the fools including nps, kdf and kasongo's chronies) were overwhelmed. some stupid fools played judge on innocent kenyans and ruled their execution in cold blood, unarmed, even with a head-shot to the back of the head. we are in april 2025, in less than 2 months we shall be in june again, no one has been brought to justice, either legally or by 'other' means. kasongo keeps breathing, telling us to live within our means, ipoa wamepoa, citizen tv na kina sam gituku walisema victims wa the occupy parliament protests ni kina ichungwa. the only 'sweet' thing, though nothing similar to the sweet i know, is bbc news africa. this documentary seems to mark the start of closure for most of us. and i hope for the families too. we know who did it: john kaboi, nps, kdf, ruto. we know their faces even. we know the victims, we have seen the victims' mothers, how they were normal people like us, trying to figure out life together in this ruto regime, that they had dreams like us, and they did not commit treason, we did not commit treason. i am an african man, and i cried a lot watching this. thank you, bbc news africa, young ademba alans, may you never lack. may the families live to find closure. we are sorry for the heroic sons and daughters you (the families) lost in the fight for a better homeland for us all. may the souls of our departed hunt ruto from all the seven hells. we will never be scared.

author: @efootball-ian
text: the bbc’s “blood parliament” exposé on kenyan security forces killing unarmed protesters during the june 2024 anti-tax protests is harrowing. clear evidence shows deliberate shootings, yet the government stalls on accountability, fueling public outrage on x. the bbc’s rigorous journalism shines, but without justice, it’s a hollow victory. this reveals a broken system where state violence trumps citizens’ rights. kenya must prosecute those responsible and reform protest policing to rebuild trust. otherwise, it’s just another unpunished tragedy.

author: @peterkung-u9519
text: 💔💔⚰ i ee mungu nguvu yetu ilete baraka kwetu haki iwe ngao na mlinzi natukae na undugu amani na uhuru raha tupate na ustawi. ii amkeni ndugu zetu tufanye sote bidii nasi tujitoe kwa nguvu nchi yetu ya kenya tunayoipenda tuwe tayari kuilinda iii natujenge taifa letu ee, ndio wajibu wetu kenya istahili heshima tuungane mikono pamoja kazini kila siku tuwe na shukran abdi kadir shot during protests in june 2024, died in hospital on july 16, 2024. rex kanyike (or rex masai) shot and killed in nairobi on june 20, 2024, one of the earliest casualties. a 29-year-old casino worker, his death became a rallying point. shot by a plainclothes officer, per his mother, gillian munyau. evans kiratu killed after being hit by a tear gas canister in nairobi on june 20, 2024. a 21-year-old whose death was confirmed by the kenya human rights commission. eric shieni university student killed outside parliament in nairobi on june 25, 2024. named in the bbc africa eye documentary blood parliament as one of three unarmed protesters shot by security forces. david chege jkuat graduate and freelance it professional killed in nairobi on june 25, 2024. also named in the blood parliament documentary as shot by security forces. ibrahim kamau killed during the protests, specific date and location unclear (likely june 25, 2024, in nairobi). kennedy onyango 12-year-old killed by a stray bullet in ongata rongai, kajiado county, on june 25, 2024, while fetching a textbook. shot in the shoulder, per autopsy. beasley kamau killed during the protests, specific details unclear (likely june 2024). charles ngere killed during the protests, specific details unclear (likely june 2024). mukei killed during the protests, specific details unclear (likely june 2024). charles owino 19-year-old killed by a gunshot to the head in kitengela, kajiado county, on july 16, 2024, during anti-government protests. his death was recorded by police as a road accident, raising allegations of a cover-up. obienge killed in kitengela, kajiado county, on july 16, 2024, same day and location as charles owino. specific details sparse. ericsson mutisya killed in nairobi on june 25, 2024, during the parliament protests. named in the blood parliament documentary as shot by security forces. unnamed protester in kitengela (july 16, 2024): a reuters reporter witnessed a protester killed in kitengela with a head wound, but no name was provided. additional unnamed victims: knchr reported 39 deaths by july 1, 2024, and up to 50 by mid-july, but most victims remain unnamed in public reports. the kenya medical association reported 13 deaths on june 25, 2024, alone, with unverified claims of dozens more. sources and verification the names above are sourced from: reuters (e.g., charles owino, obienge, rex kanyike): detailed investigations into specific deaths. pulselive kenya (e.g., abdi kadir, evans kiratu): lists confirmed casualties. bbc and al jazeera (e.g., kennedy onyango, rex masai): verified reports with victim details. x posts (e.g., david chege, ericsson mutisya): mentioned in blood parliament documentary discussions, treated as inconclusive but cross-referenced with other sources. knchr and rights groups: provide death tolls but limited names.

text: i remember this day and how the events unfolded. what started as a small group of protesters along muindi mbingu street and how it all garnered momentum to fill every street and charge towards the parliament. the chaos that ensued, followed by looting and burning of buildings. sunbeam and uganda house were on fire as we exited cbd on foot towards jogoo road. it was like leaving a war field, police were firing aimless shots at protesters in down town ronald ngala street. i will never forget the horror and ordeal. rip to the brave souls of our beloved countrymen.
